alt_statements.statement: I think we have to protect the environment because our kids are the ones who will live with what we leave behind, but we can’t just shut down jobs that families depend on overnight. The government should push companies to be cleaner—like using greener energy and cutting pollution—while also making sure workers get training and support so they don’t lose their income. For me, real growth means people have good jobs, clean air, and safe neighborhoods at the same time, not one instead of the other.

As a mom and someone who tries to stay informed, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need to build our economy around clean energy and long-term sustainability so our kids aren’t stuck paying for our short-sightedness. Climate policy should prioritize aggressive emissions reductions and environmental safeguards, while also supporting workers and communities with good jobs, retraining, and investment in green industries.

Climate policy has to respect economic reality: we can’t sacrifice jobs, retirement savings, and American competitiveness on the altar of abstract targets. I support pragmatic, market-driven solutions—like incentivizing cleaner technologies, nuclear energy, and private-sector innovation—rather than heavy-handed regulation that punishes business and investors. We should protect the environment responsibly, but always with an eye on growth, energy reliability, and keeping America strong and prosperous for working families and retirees alike.

I believe we have a responsibility, as stewards of God’s creation, to protect the environment, but we also need to be realistic about the impact strict regulations can have on jobs, energy prices, and seniors on fixed incomes. Climate policy should focus on practical, market-based solutions—like encouraging cleaner technology, energy efficiency, and innovation in American industry—rather than heavy-handed mandates that slow economic growth. We can make meaningful environmental progress by supporting responsible businesses, investing in resilient infrastructure, and promoting individual responsibility, without sacrificing the economic stability that families and retirees depend on.

As a conservative and a taxpayer who works in our local school system, I believe we need climate policies that protect our air, water, and farmland without strangling the economy that funds our communities and schools. We should focus on practical, cost‑effective solutions—like encouraging innovation in cleaner energy, improving efficiency, and using market incentives—rather than sweeping mandates that hurt small businesses and working families. Environmental protection matters, but it has to be balanced with keeping energy affordable, jobs secure, and our local economies strong for the sake of our kids’ future.

As someone who teaches for a living and wants my kids to inherit a livable world, I see environmental protection as a precondition for long-term economic growth, not something that competes with it. Climate policy should prioritize aggressive emissions reductions and investment in clean technologies, even if that means short-term costs or regulation for certain industries, because the economic and human costs of inaction will be far greater. At the same time, we need thoughtful transition policies—job training, community investment, and support for vulnerable families—so that the move to a greener economy is both just and broadly shared.

As someone who works in a state-run food service and cares deeply about my community, I believe climate policy has to put environmental protection first while still respecting the need for stable jobs and economic security. We can’t keep chasing short-term growth if it destroys the air, water, and climate our neighborhoods depend on, but we also have to invest in a just transition—training workers, especially in working-class and immigrant communities, for cleaner, better-paying jobs. For me, real economic growth means healthier communities, more resilient local food systems, and policies that hold big polluters accountable instead of leaving ordinary people to pay the price.

As someone working in construction finance and raising a family, I believe climate policy has to protect the environment in a practical way without crippling jobs, growth, or household budgets. We should focus on cost-effective measures and new technologies that reduce emissions while keeping energy reliable and affordable, rather than sweeping regulations that hit businesses and workers hardest. I support gradual, market-driven changes with clear timelines so companies can plan and families aren’t blindsided by higher costs.

Having spent a career in finance and now devoting my time to environmental work, I’m convinced that framing climate policy as a tug-of-war between the economy and the environment is outdated and dangerous. We should prioritize strong environmental protections and aggressive decarbonization, and use smart market design, regulation, and public investment to drive innovation and create good jobs in the process. The real economic risk isn’t from bold climate action, but from clinging to a carbon-heavy status quo that will leave communities, markets, and ecosystems far more unstable in the long run.

I care a lot about the outdoors and want clean air, water, and healthy forests for my grandkids someday, but I also know that people like me depend on steady work to keep a roof over our heads—literally and figuratively. Climate policy should aim for practical solutions that protect the environment without killing good-paying jobs or driving up costs for working families. We ought to focus on commonsense measures like incentivizing cleaner technologies, improving efficiency, and managing our resources wisely, not heavy-handed regulations that punish small businesses and workers.

I believe we have a responsibility before God and to our grandchildren to be good stewards of the earth, but we also have to use common sense so we don’t destroy people’s livelihoods in the process. Climate policies should encourage practical steps like cleaner technology, conservation, and American energy independence, without piling on regulations and costs that hurt small businesses and working families.

As a working mom and the primary earner for my family, I believe climate policy has to protect both the environment and the livelihoods of people who depend on industries like mine. We should invest in realistic, market-driven technologies that reduce emissions over time—like efficiency improvements and cleaner production—without killing jobs or driving up costs for families. I’m for conservation and responsible stewardship of the planet, but I don’t support extreme regulations that hurt small businesses and American competitiveness while countries like China keep polluting.

As someone who makes a modest living as a working musician, I understand how fragile people’s livelihoods can be, but I also see climate change as an even bigger threat to our long-term economic and personal well-being. I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, with strong investments in clean energy and green jobs so workers and small businesses aren’t left behind. We shouldn’t accept the false choice between the planet and paychecks—smart regulation, innovation, and fair transition support can grow the economy while honoring our moral responsibility, as a Catholic and a citizen, to care for creation and for each other.

I think we need to protect God’s creation, but we also can’t forget that folks need steady jobs and affordable gas and electricity to support their families. Climate policy should focus on practical, common-sense steps—like encouraging cleaner but reliable energy, improving efficiency in trucks and logistics, and promoting innovation—without piling on regulations that crush small businesses or drive up costs.

I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, because if we wreck the planet there won’t be an economy left to grow, but it also needs to support workers and communities so people aren’t left behind. We should invest heavily in clean energy, green jobs, and retraining programs so that economic growth comes from technologies and industries that actually reduce emissions instead of making things worse.

I think protecting the environment matters, but we can’t wreck people’s jobs and the economy to do it. We should push for realistic solutions like cleaner technology, better energy efficiency, and responsible use of resources without shutting down businesses or driving up costs for working families. Climate policies need to respect personal responsibility and the free market, letting innovation lead instead of heavy government mandates.

We need to protect the land and water God gave us, but we also have to be realistic about people’s livelihoods and the cost of living. Climate policy should focus on practical measures that don’t destroy jobs or make energy unaffordable for working people and seniors on fixed incomes. I support gradual, market-based solutions and better technology, not heavy-handed regulations that hurt small businesses and raise everyone’s bills.

As a cop and a dad, I want my kids growing up in a world where the air’s clean and the weather’s not getting more dangerous every year, but I also know families around here depend on steady jobs and affordable living. We should push hard on clean energy, public transit, and efficiency standards, not just because it’s good for the planet, but because it can create stable, middle‑class jobs and reduce long‑term costs from disasters and health problems. To me, the right balance is setting strong environmental rules and timelines, then backing workers and small businesses with training, incentives, and support so they’re not left behind in the transition. That way we’re protecting both public safety and economic security, instead of pretending we have to sacrifice one for the other.

Climate policy has to protect our land and communities, but it can’t cripple the economy or punish working families and small businesses in the process. I support reasonable, evidence-based environmental regulations that encourage innovation and cleaner technology, but I don’t believe in extreme measures that kill jobs, raise energy prices, or put us at a disadvantage against countries like China. The right balance is investing in practical solutions—like improving grid reliability, supporting nuclear and natural gas, and incentivizing businesses to cut emissions—without overregulating or growing government control.

At my age I’ve seen that chasing short-term profit while ignoring the health of our air, water, and land always costs us more in the long run, especially for working families and the poor. We need strong climate policies that aggressively cut pollution and invest in clean energy, but also provide support and new job opportunities for workers and communities that depend on older industries. As a Christian, I see caring for creation as a moral duty, and as a Democrat, I believe government should lead in making sure that transition is fair and doesn’t leave people behind.

As someone who came from Cambodia to build a better life here, I believe we should protect the environment in a way that doesn’t punish hardworking families and small businesses. Climate policies need to focus on practical solutions like encouraging cleaner technologies, improving energy efficiency, and supporting innovation in the private sector, rather than heavy-handed regulations that raise prices and cost people their jobs. We can be good stewards of God’s creation while still promoting strong economic growth and opportunity, especially for immigrants and working-class Americans.

I’ve worked the land my whole life, and I know you can’t keep taking from the soil or the air without giving something back, or it’ll quit on you. That said, we can’t be shutting down farms, small businesses, and energy jobs in the name of climate policy cooked up by folks who never got dirt under their nails. We need practical, affordable steps that cut waste and pollution—like better equipment, smarter water use, and sensible energy improvements—without strangling the rural economy or driving up costs for people on fixed incomes. Protect God’s creation, yes, but do it in a way that keeps food on the table and towns alive.

At my age, looking back over decades of teaching history, it’s clear that societies that chew through their natural resources for short-term gain always pay a higher price later. We ought to treat environmental protection as the foundation of long-term economic health, not an obstacle to it—investing in clean energy, conservation, and green infrastructure can create good jobs while preserving a livable planet for our grandchildren. As a progressive and a Catholic, I see this as both prudent public policy and a moral obligation to safeguard creation and care for the most vulnerable, who suffer first and worst from climate change.

As someone who does hands-on work in buildings every day, I see how much energy we waste and how small changes—better insulation, smarter lighting, efficient systems—can cut costs and pollution at the same time. We shouldn’t treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposites; smart climate policy can create good, stable jobs, especially in building retrofits and green infrastructure, while protecting the communities we live in. As a liberal Democrat and a Jew, I feel a moral responsibility to care for the earth and for vulnerable people who’ll be hit hardest by climate change. So I support aggressive climate action that invests in clean technology, worker protections, and community-based programs, even if it means short-term costs for long-term justice and prosperity.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because my generation is the one that’s going to live with the worst consequences if we don’t. But I also know a lot of families, especially in Latino communities, depend on jobs that could be affected by climate rules, so climate policy should invest in clean energy, job training, and support for workers. To me, real economic growth means creating sustainable jobs that don’t poison our air and water, not just chasing profits right now.

As someone who’s worked hard my whole life for a modest paycheck, I don’t think protecting the environment and having a strong economy should be treated like an either-or choice. We need climate policies that move us toward clean energy and stricter environmental standards, but they should also protect workers and keep basic goods affordable for people like me. With smart regulation, investment in green jobs, and help for communities that rely on older industries, we can have both a healthier planet and a fairer economy.

I think we should protect the environment even if it slows down some kinds of economic growth, because our future and our health depend on clean air, water, and a stable climate. But I also see how my family and people in my neighborhood need jobs and affordable food, so climate policies should help create new, greener jobs, like in clean energy or sustainable farming, instead of just shutting things down.

At my age, I’ve seen how chasing short-term economic gains without regard for the environment always seems to leave ordinary people paying the price later. I believe climate policy should put environmental protection first, with smart, steady investments in clean energy and infrastructure that also create good jobs and help communities—especially those with fewer resources—transition fairly. Economic growth that destroys the planet we leave to our grandchildren isn’t really “growth” at all; it’s a debt we’re passing on.

We need to protect the environment, but we can’t cripple the economy or people’s ability to earn a living in the process. Climate policy should focus on practical steps—like cleaner technology and better efficiency in factories—without piling on regulations and costs that send jobs overseas or shut down plants. I’m fine with reasonable rules that keep the air and water clean, but they need to be gradual, realistic, and support American workers first.

I think we should protect nature first, because if the air, water, and animals get ruined, then there won’t be a good world left for us when we grow up. Grown‑ups can still make money and have businesses, but they should do it in ways that don’t hurt the Earth so much, like using clean energy and not wasting stuff.

I like it when the trees and animals are safe, because my teacher says we need them to breathe and live, so I think grown-ups should protect nature first. But I also know my parents work hard for money, so I think we should use new smart things, like clean energy, that help the Earth and still let people have jobs and nice houses.

I think we should protect nature a lot because we only have one Earth, and if we ruin it, kids like me won’t have clean air or safe places to play. Grown‑ups should still be able to have jobs and make money, but they should do it in ways that don’t hurt the planet so much, like using cleaner energy and making less trash. If we take care of the environment now, it will help people and the economy in the future too.

As someone who has worn a badge for decades, I believe in protecting our home and our people, but also in being realistic about what working families and small businesses can afford. We should invest in practical environmental measures—like cleaner infrastructure, resilient energy grids, and better disaster preparedness—that create jobs and keep communities safe, instead of imposing heavy-handed regulations that kill industries and raise costs. Climate policy should reward innovation and responsible behavior, not punish those who are just trying to make an honest living.

As someone who works in online retail and cares a lot about health, I see environmental protection and economic growth as deeply connected, not competing goals. We should push for strong climate policies that prioritize clean energy, energy-efficient products, and sustainable business practices, because a healthy planet ultimately supports stable jobs, lower healthcare costs, and better quality of life. Government should help businesses—especially smaller ones—transition with incentives and training rather than just penalties, so workers like me aren’t left behind. In the long run, sacrificing the environment for short-term profit is bad economics and bad for our communities.

As someone who built a law practice from scratch and also comes from a country that has seen both environmental degradation and oil-fueled growth, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing sides so much as terms that need to be harmonized in the same “contract.” Climate policy should aggressively reduce emissions and protect vulnerable ecosystems, but it should do so by driving innovation—clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and green jobs—so that we’re not just restricting economic activity, we’re restructuring it. A truly fair, feminist, and Christian-informed approach insists that the costs of transition not fall hardest on workers and marginalized communities, and that long-term human flourishing—not short-term profit—be the standard by which policies are judged.

I believe we should protect the environment, but not in a way that destroys people’s livelihoods or drives up prices for working families. Climate policies ought to encourage practical solutions—like cleaner technology, better energy efficiency, and incentives for businesses to innovate—rather than heavy-handed regulations and taxes. We can be good stewards of God’s creation while still allowing our economy to grow and our communities to thrive.

Working in manufacturing, I see firsthand how regulations can feel like a burden, but I also see how much waste and energy we burn through, and I don’t think we can just ignore that for the sake of short-term profit. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, with strong standards, but pair that with incentives and support to help companies modernize—especially in places like North Carolina where good jobs matter. If we invest in cleaner tech and energy efficiency, we can protect the places I love to hike and still grow the economy in a more sustainable way.

As a software developer, I see climate policy a bit like good system design: you don’t choose between performance and security—you architect for both from the start. We should prioritize strong environmental protection and use innovation, clean energy, and green infrastructure to drive economic growth, especially because my kids will live with the long-term consequences of what we do now. Smart regulation and market incentives can push businesses to adapt and compete in new, sustainable industries rather than clinging to outdated, polluting models. In the long run, a healthy environment is the foundation of a resilient economy, not a trade-off against it.

As a young Navajo mom who’s still in school and trying to make ends meet, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need both, but the planet has to set the limits. Climate policy should protect the land, air, and water first, because without those there is no real economy, and at the same time invest in clean energy jobs, better schools, and infrastructure so families like mine in New Mexico can have real opportunities.

I think we should take care of the trees, animals, and sky first, because if the Earth gets sick, people and jobs will get hurt too. Grown‑ups should make rules so companies don’t hurt the air and water, but also help them find cleaner ways to make money, like using the sun and wind.

As a dad trying to raise kids on a modest income, I can’t ignore either the need for good jobs or the need for a livable planet they can grow up in. Climate policy should push clean energy, public transit, and energy‑efficient housing in a way that creates affordable jobs and opportunities, especially in working‑class and Black communities that often get hit first and worst by pollution. We shouldn’t treat environmental protection and economic growth as enemies; smart policy can protect our air and water while helping people like me find stable work in the new green economy.

As a teacher and someone who spends a lot of peaceful time outdoors, I feel strongly that environmental protection has to be the foundation of any economic growth we pursue. Without a stable climate and healthy ecosystems, the economy our students will inherit simply won’t be sustainable. That said, I think climate policy should also support good jobs and help communities transition—especially working families—so people aren’t forced to choose between their livelihoods and the planet. Thoughtful regulations, clean energy investments, and support for affected workers can align long-term prosperity with serious environmental responsibility.

As someone who’s lived long enough to see how polluted rivers can become clean again and how jobs can disappear when we don’t plan ahead, I don’t think we should treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposites. We should invest heavily in clean energy, conservation, and green infrastructure, creating stable, good-paying jobs while preserving the climate for our grandchildren and the natural world I cherish in my garden. If we insist on short-term profits over long-term sustainability, we’ll end up paying far more—economically, morally, and spiritually—down the line.

As someone who works in public education and spends most of my free time in nature, I believe strong environmental protection has to be the starting point, not an afterthought, in climate policy. That said, I don’t think protecting the environment and economic growth are opposites—if we invest in clean energy, green infrastructure, and resilient communities, we can create good, stable jobs while cutting emissions. Local and federal policies should prioritize long-term sustainability over short-term profit, especially for working families and public services like schools that will bear the costs of climate disasters.

I think we should protect the environment first, because if we ruin the Earth, there won’t be a good place for anyone to work or make money anyway. Grown-ups should use their businesses and science to make cleaner energy and less pollution, even if it costs more at the start, because God gave us this world to take care of, not just to use up.

I think protecting nature should come first, because this is the only planet we have and kids like me have to live with what adults decide now. It’s okay to think about money and jobs, but climate policies should make sure companies don’t hurt the air, water, and animals, even if it costs more. A good balance is when we find smart, clean ways to grow the economy that don’t ruin the environment, so everyone can live safely and fairly.

As a dad and someone who works in a business that depends on people driving, I think we’ve got to be smart about climate policy so it protects the environment without crushing working families’ budgets. We should push cleaner technologies and energy efficiency in ways that create good jobs and keep gas and utility prices manageable, instead of sudden rules that make it hard for regular folks to get to work or support their kids. I believe we can balance both by phasing in realistic standards, supporting innovation, and helping workers and small businesses adapt, rather than treating the economy and the environment like they’re enemies.

I think we need a climate policy that protects our air and water without killing the jobs and industries that keep families like mine afloat. I work with machines, and I know there are practical ways to make equipment cleaner and more efficient over time, but forcing sudden, expensive changes hurts workers and small businesses the most. Let’s focus on realistic, market-driven improvements and innovation instead of heavy-handed regulations that slow down the economy.

As someone who runs a busy kitchen and depends on a strong local economy, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—smart climate policy can and should drive innovation, create jobs, and keep small businesses like mine thriving. We should invest heavily in clean energy, sustainable agriculture, and greener supply chains, while offering support and transition help to workers and industries that have to adapt. My kids’ future matters more than short-term profit, so when there’s a tradeoff, we should err on the side of protecting the climate—but do it in a way that rewards creativity and fairness rather than just adding red tape.

As someone who’s spent his life in the law, I believe good climate policy has to protect God’s creation without crippling the livelihoods of working families and small businesses. We ought to pursue reasonable, market-driven solutions—like encouraging innovation, cleaner technology, and conservation—rather than heavy-handed regulations that choke off growth. If we’re thoughtful, we can keep our air and water clean, preserve the birds and lands I love to watch on a quiet morning, and still maintain a strong, competitive economy that offers opportunity to the next generation.

Growing up in Arkansas, I’ve seen how closely folks’ livelihoods are tied to the land, so I don’t buy the idea that we have to choose between a healthy environment and a healthy economy. Climate policy ought to put strong protections on air, water, and soil first, then support workers and communities in transitioning to cleaner industries so they’re not left high and dry. If we plan ahead and invest wisely—especially in disadvantaged communities—we can create good jobs while preserving the planet our grandchildren will inherit, even if we don’t have any little ones under our own roof.

As someone who drives for a living and sees the city’s smog and traffic up close every day, I think it’s obvious we can’t keep treating the environment as an afterthought to growth. We need strong climate policies that aggressively push clean energy and public transit, but they should also support workers and small businesses through the transition—grants for cleaner vehicles, better infrastructure, and retraining where needed. Environmental protection and economic growth don’t have to be enemies if we’re willing to invest smartly and make the long-term health of people and the planet the priority.

As a business manager, a dad, and an immigrant who chose this country, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need climate policy that aggressively cuts emissions while driving innovation, better jobs, and long‑term competitiveness. I’d rather see us invest in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and science‑driven standards now than saddle my kids with the costs of climate disasters later, both moral and financial.

I think we’ve got to be smart about protecting the land and air without killing the jobs and small businesses that keep towns like mine alive. I’m all for cleaner energy and not trashing the outdoors I love to hike in, but climate rules shouldn’t be written by people who’ve never swung a hammer or lived paycheck to paycheck. We should push for practical, affordable steps that improve efficiency and reduce waste, not policies that shut down industries overnight and leave working folks with no way to provide for themselves.

As someone who spends weekends outside with my kids and sees firsthand how much they thrive in clean air and open spaces, I think environmental protection has to set the boundaries within which economic growth happens, not the other way around. We can absolutely grow our economy, but it needs to be through green jobs, clean energy, and smarter infrastructure that don’t mortgage our kids’ futures. As a teacher, I want to be honest with my students: kicking the can down the road on climate might look like growth on paper, but it’s a bad deal for their generation.

As someone who’s built a good career and a stable life here, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need smart climate policies that drive innovation, create green jobs, and protect the communities that are usually hit first and worst by pollution and extreme weather. My values as a liberal, a Jewish woman, and an immigrant from Trinidad and Tobago push me to support aggressive climate action with strong safeguards for workers and small businesses, so the transition is fair and doesn’t leave anyone behind.

As a healthcare professional and small business owner, I see environmental protection and economic growth as deeply interconnected rather than competing goals. Climate policy should aggressively reduce emissions and protect public health, while also supporting businesses—especially in healthcare and other essential services—through incentives, clear regulations, and investment in clean technologies. As a liberal and a parent, I’m willing to accept short-term economic adjustments and higher standards if it means a healthier, more stable climate and lower disease burden for my kids’ generation. The right balance is strong, science-based environmental protections paired with smart economic tools that help workers and communities transition rather than be left behind.

As someone who works in air transportation and cares about both the economy and the environment, I think climate policy should focus on practical, market-driven solutions that reduce emissions without crippling businesses or costing people their jobs. We should incentivize cleaner technologies, improve efficiency, and support innovation in industries like aviation, rather than imposing heavy-handed regulations that slow growth. Economic strength gives us the resources to invest in conservation and environmental protection, so the goal should be steady, realistic progress that keeps America competitive while being good stewards of God’s creation.

Working in the private sector and seeing how many people depend on steady jobs, I think climate policy has to protect both the environment and folks’ livelihoods, not pit them against each other. We should push for cleaner energy and smarter regulations that cut emissions, but do it in ways that give businesses time and incentives to adapt, invest, and innovate. If we approach this practically—using market-based tools, technology, and gradual standards—we can protect the planet without choking off the economic growth that supports working people.

As a mom trying to raise kids on a cashier’s paycheck, I care a lot about the environment, but I can’t support climate policies that kill jobs or make energy and everyday goods too expensive for working families. We should focus on practical solutions—like encouraging businesses to innovate cleaner technologies and use energy more efficiently—without heavy-handed government mandates or regulations that hurt small towns and middle- and lower-income workers. In my view, protecting God’s creation and supporting economic growth can go hand in hand if we put American workers and families first in any climate plan.

As someone who works in public service and cares deeply about my community, I see environmental protection and economic growth as goals that have to move together, not in opposition. We need strong climate policies that aggressively cut emissions and protect our land and water, especially for Native and rural communities who are often hit first and hardest, while investing in good-paying, union-friendly green jobs and retraining so working families aren’t left behind.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because if we ruin our air, water, and climate, there won’t be a healthy future or real economy for my generation. But I don’t think it has to be “environment vs. jobs” – the government and businesses should invest in clean energy, green jobs, and helping communities, especially Black communities that are often hit hardest by pollution, transition fairly. As a Catholic, I’ve learned we’re supposed to be good stewards of God’s creation and care for the poor, so climate policies should focus on both protecting the Earth and making sure families can still work, learn, and live with dignity.

Living here in Georgia, I’ve seen how closely our livelihoods are tied to the land and the weather, so I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need both, and we can get both if we’re smart about it. Climate policy ought to prioritize transitioning to clean energy, conservation, and green jobs, especially in caregiving and community services, because a healthy environment supports long-term economic stability. I’d rather see us invest now in sustainable industries and resilience than pay a much higher price later in disasters, healthcare costs, and lost communities.

As a mother and a homemaker, I want clean air, safe water, and a stable climate for my kids, but I also know families like mine depend on steady jobs and affordable energy. I believe we should support practical, market-based solutions—like incentives for cleaner technologies, conservation, and responsible use of resources—without crushing small businesses or driving up costs for working families. To me, the right balance is encouraging innovation and personal responsibility, not heavy-handed regulations that hurt our economy and our communities.

I think we can’t just ignore climate change, because it’s already affecting people’s lives and will only get worse for my generation, but I also get that a lot of families around here depend on jobs in energy and industry. Climate policy should push cleaner technology and energy gradually, so we’re cutting emissions and protecting God’s creation without suddenly wiping out people’s livelihoods.

Para mí, cuidar el medio ambiente y crecer económicamente no son cosas opuestas, se necesitan las dos. Yo trabajo con autos y sé que la gente depende de su trabajo para vivir, pero también veo cómo la contaminación nos afecta la salud. El gobierno debería apoyar tecnologías más limpias y ayudar a las empresas pequeñas y a los trabajadores a adaptarse, para que no perdamos nuestros empleos mientras hacemos las cosas de una manera más responsable. Una buena política climática es la que protege la tierra para nuestros hijos y al mismo tiempo garantiza trabajo justo y estable para la comunidad.

I believe we need to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to use common sense so we don’t cripple our local businesses and families with excessive regulations. Climate policy should focus on practical, affordable steps—like encouraging cleaner technologies and conservation—without shutting down industries or driving up energy costs for people on fixed incomes. We can protect our environment while still keeping our economy healthy if we work gradually, listen to local communities, and avoid one-size-fits-all mandates from Washington.

I don’t understand climate policy yet, but the grown‑ups who love me keep saying the world I grow up in needs clean air, safe water, and a stable climate more than it needs quick money. Protecting the environment should come first, and then we can build an economy that creates jobs and opportunities without hurting the planet, especially for kids like me who will live with the consequences the longest.

As someone who works in finance and values both long-term stability and social responsibility, I see environmental protection and economic growth as mutually reinforcing rather than competing goals. Climate policy should aggressively reduce emissions and invest in clean energy and resilient infrastructure, while using market-based tools and smart regulation to drive innovation and protect jobs. If we internalize environmental costs and plan ahead, we can grow the economy in a way that safeguards public health, preserves creation, and avoids much higher financial and human costs down the road.

I think we need a balanced approach where we protect the environment without crippling the businesses and workers our communities depend on. Climate policy should focus on practical steps like encouraging cleaner energy and better technology through incentives, not heavy-handed regulations that drive up costs for families and small towns. We can be good stewards of God’s creation while still keeping our economy strong and preserving people’s jobs and way of life.

As someone running a small advertising agency and raising young kids, I want strong climate policies that prioritize environmental protection while giving businesses like mine clear, stable rules to innovate and grow. We shouldn’t treat climate action and economic growth as opposites—smart investments in clean energy, green infrastructure, and sustainable practices can create good jobs and new markets. I’d support policies that phase out the worst polluters, reward companies that cut emissions, and ensure working families aren’t stuck with the bill. Ultimately, protecting the planet my kids will inherit is more important than short-term profits for big corporations, but it’s on government and industry to make the transition fair and practical.

We need a sensible balance that protects God’s creation without strangling the jobs and businesses hardworking people depend on. I support practical, market-based steps to reduce pollution and encourage cleaner technologies, but I don’t believe in heavy-handed regulations that drive up energy costs for families and small companies. Climate policy should focus on innovation, efficiency, and responsible use of our resources, not on punishing the very workers who keep this country running.

As a chemical engineer in pharmaceutical manufacturing, I see firsthand that innovation and strict environmental standards are not mutually exclusive—if anything, they tend to drive each other. Climate policy should prioritize strong, science-based environmental protections while using market incentives and transitional support to push industry toward cleaner technologies, so economic growth comes from decarbonization rather than despite it. In the long term, any growth that depends on degrading the climate is scientifically unsustainable and ethically irresponsible, so we should treat environmental limits as hard constraints and compete on how efficiently and creatively we can thrive within them.

As someone who makes a living as an independent musician, I see firsthand how fragile both our environment and our economic stability can be, especially for people who aren’t protected by big institutions. I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, because a damaged planet ultimately destroys any possibility of sustainable growth—but it should do so by actively investing in green industries, cultural work, and local communities so that people can thrive while we transition. We shouldn’t accept the old narrative that jobs and the planet are in conflict; instead, we should be funding innovation, clean energy, and the arts as part of a more humane, low-carbon economy.

As someone who cares about both my community’s future and having real opportunities, I think climate policy has to treat environmental protection and economic growth as linked, not competing. We should invest heavily in clean energy, green infrastructure, and environmental justice, especially in Black and low-income neighborhoods that usually get hit first and worst, so we’re creating good jobs while cutting pollution. If we do it right, protecting the planet can actually be the engine for fair, long-term economic growth instead of something that holds it back.

Spending a career as a park ranger taught me that healthy forests, clean water, and stable wildlife populations are the real “infrastructure” that keep communities and economies alive. Climate policy ought to put environmental protection first, and then let economic growth adapt around those limits through green jobs, conservation work, and renewable energy. Short‑term profit that destroys ecosystems just passes a bigger bill—financial and moral—onto the next generation. A strong, nature‑focused climate policy is the most responsible investment we can make in long‑term prosperity.

I think we’ve got to be smart about climate policy so we don’t wreck the livelihoods of working folks in the process. We should push for cleaner energy and better building standards, but do it in a way that keeps construction jobs strong and energy costs reasonable, especially for families just trying to get by. I’m all for protecting the outdoors I hike in and the woods I love, but regulations should be practical, phased in, and focused on innovation and efficiency rather than punishing businesses. In my view, hard work and common sense can get us to a place where we protect the environment without strangling economic growth.

As a mom, a teacher, and someone who wants my kids to grow up with clean air and safe weather, I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, but in a way that supports working families and creates good jobs. We shouldn’t accept the idea that we have to choose between a healthy planet and a strong economy—investing in renewable energy, green infrastructure, and energy‑efficient schools can create stable, middle‑class jobs while cutting pollution. Environmental rollbacks that boost short‑term profits but harm children’s health and future are not worth it, especially when we have the technology and resources to grow our economy sustainably.

As someone working in manufacturing and seeing how jobs depend on steady business, I don’t think we can ignore the economy when we talk about climate policy—but we also can’t keep treating the planet like it’s disposable. We need strong environmental regulations that push companies to clean up and innovate, paired with support and retraining so workers don’t get left behind. To me, real growth is when we create good-paying, green jobs that protect our communities’ health and future. As a liberal and a Christian, I see caring for creation and for working people as the same responsibility, not competing priorities.

I think climate policy should put environmental protection first, because if we wreck the planet, there won’t be an economy or a future for kids like me anyway. But I also think we need to create new green jobs and training so people, especially in working-class and diverse communities, aren’t left behind as things change. Instead of pretending we have to choose between the planet and paychecks, we should invest in clean energy, public transit, and sustainable agriculture that protect the environment while giving people real opportunities.

Working in finance, I see every day how short-term profit can blind people to long-term risk, and climate change is the biggest systemic risk we’re facing. We shouldn’t frame environmental protection and economic growth as opposites; smart climate policy—like investing in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and green jobs—can drive sustainable growth while cutting emissions. I’d support strong regulations and carbon pricing, paired with support for workers and communities in transitioning industries, so we’re not sacrificing people’s livelihoods but retooling them for a different future. In my view, if growth isn’t compatible with a livable planet, then it’s not responsible growth.

As someone living simply with no income and no safety net like health insurance, I’m acutely aware that economic security matters—but I don’t think it should come at the expense of a livable planet. My Jewish values and commitment to social justice push me to support climate policies that aggressively cut emissions while investing in green jobs, worker retraining, and community supports so vulnerable people aren’t left behind. Environmental protection has to set the outer limits—no policies that lock us into climate catastrophe—but within those limits, we should use clean innovation and public investment to build a fair, sustainable economy.

As someone who worked hard to build a business and provide a comfortable life for my family, I believe climate policy must protect the environment without crippling the economy that supports American workers and retirees. We should focus on practical, market-based solutions—like incentivizing cleaner technologies and improving energy efficiency—rather than sweeping regulations that drive up costs for small businesses and households. A strong economy gives us the resources to invest in conservation and stewardship of God’s creation, so the goal should be smart, balanced policies, not ideological extremes.

At my age, I’ve seen how hardworking people, especially in healthcare and other modest jobs, depend on a strong economy to keep food on the table and medicine paid for. I believe we should protect God’s creation and be good stewards of the earth, but climate policies must be practical, gradual, and not crush small businesses or drive up costs for ordinary folks on fixed incomes. I’d support cleaner technology and reasonable regulations that encourage innovation and American energy independence, rather than heavy-handed rules that hurt jobs and raise utility bills.

I think we’ve got to protect the environment because it’s literally the world we live and work in, but we also can’t just slam the brakes on businesses and jobs people rely on. Climate policy should push companies toward cleaner energy and less waste in practical, step-by-step ways that don’t crush small restaurants, drivers, and working folks. If we invest in cleaner tech and better infrastructure, we can create new jobs while cutting pollution instead of treating it like a choice between the planet and a paycheck.

I think we should protect nature a lot, because I really like bugs and trees and I want them to still be here when I grow up. Grown‑ups can still make money and build things, but they should do it in ways that don’t hurt the air, water, or animals so much. If we take care of the Earth, then people can have jobs and also have a nice, clean place to live and play.

Where I’m from, you learn pretty quick that if you strip the land bare for a quick buck, you pay for it down the road—same goes for the climate. I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites; if we invest in clean energy, sustainable materials, and circular business models, we can create good-paying jobs that don’t poison our air and water. Climate policy should put strict limits on pollution and carbon, but give businesses clear incentives and support to innovate so workers and communities—especially in places like Tennessee—aren’t left holding the bag. In my mind, long-term prosperity depends on treating a stable climate and healthy ecosystems as the non-negotiable foundation of the economy, not an optional extra.

As someone who has lived long enough to see the climate change around me, I believe protecting the environment has to come first, even if it means slowing certain kinds of economic growth. Any “growth” that destroys the planet we’re leaving to future generations isn’t real progress; it’s just borrowing against their well‑being. That said, I think we can and should create jobs and new industries through clean energy and conservation, so that working people aren’t left behind as we transition to a more sustainable economy.

As someone who spent her career in environmental science, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites, but I do believe the environment has to set the boundaries within which the economy operates. Climate policy should prioritize rapid emissions reductions and ecosystem protection, while investing in clean energy, public health, and green jobs that create sustainable growth over the long term. We’ve already pushed natural systems close to their limits; any “growth” that depends on degrading air, water, and climate isn’t real prosperity, it’s borrowing against our grandchildren’s future.

As someone who manages IT projects and thinks a lot about long-term planning, I see climate policy the same way I see a critical infrastructure upgrade: you invest up front, or you pay much more later in failures and downtime. We shouldn’t frame environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals—strong, science-based climate standards can actually drive innovation, create high-quality jobs in clean tech, and make our economy more resilient for our kids’ generation. I support policies that aggressively cut emissions and incentivize green technologies while providing real transition support for workers and businesses, especially in legacy industries. That’s the balance: firm environmental guardrails, pro-growth investment in clean innovation, and a just transition so people aren’t left behind.

As someone who has watched this country change over nearly nine decades, I believe we have a duty, under God, to be good stewards of the earth—but also a responsibility to protect the livelihoods of working families. Climate policy should focus on practical, incremental measures that encourage innovation in cleaner energy and conservation without strangling our industries with excessive regulation or driving up costs for ordinary Americans. We need a balanced approach that respects both the environment and the dignity of work, rather than sweeping mandates that sound good on paper but hurt people in practice.

I believe we need a climate policy that protects our environment without strangling the businesses and jobs that keep our economy strong. Sensible, market-driven solutions—like tax incentives for cleaner technologies and targeted, cost-effective regulations—can encourage innovation without punishing companies or workers. We should prioritize realistic, gradual changes that maintain American energy independence and competitiveness, rather than sweeping mandates that drive up costs for families and small businesses.

I believe we need to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to be realistic about people’s livelihoods and the cost of living. Climate policies should focus on common-sense steps—like encouraging cleaner energy and conservation—without destroying jobs, overregulating small businesses, or driving up energy bills for working families.

I think we should protect the Earth a lot, even if it costs money, because we only have one planet and I want it to still be nice when I grow up and have kids. Grown-ups should use their money and jobs to make cleaner things, like cars and factories that don’t hurt the air so much, instead of just trying to get rich fast. In my religion we talk about taking care of the world God made, so I think it’s important that leaders choose rules that keep people working but also keep the oceans, animals, and air safe.

I believe we need a practical balance where we protect God’s creation without strangling small businesses and working folks with red tape. Climate policies should focus on common‑sense steps—like encouraging innovation, energy efficiency, and responsible land use—while keeping energy affordable and American jobs strong. As someone who runs a hardware store, I see firsthand how overregulation can hit local businesses hard, so any policy needs to be gradual, realistic, and driven by market solutions, not mandates from Washington.

I believe God made us stewards of this earth, so we do have a duty to protect it—but we also have to be practical and protect people’s jobs and the cost of living, especially for folks on fixed incomes. Climate policies should focus on common-sense steps like encouraging cleaner technologies, improving energy efficiency, and supporting American-made energy, without imposing regulations that crush small businesses or drive up utility bills. We can care for creation and still keep our economy strong by moving at a realistic pace and making sure working people and the poor aren’t the ones who pay the highest price.

We need to stop talking like protecting the environment and growing the economy are enemies; a smart, limited-government climate policy can do both by getting the rules simple, predictable, and technology-neutral. I don’t want DC micromanaging every lightbulb, but I do want strong incentives for cleaner energy, more resilience for communities, and fewer subsidies that prop up polluters or big corporations. Let markets and innovation lead the way, set clear guardrails to protect air, water, and public health, and then get out of the way so people and businesses can adapt and thrive.

As someone working in healthcare and raising kids on a modest income, I think climate policy has to protect the environment without putting so much cost on working families that we can’t get by. We should invest in cleaner technologies and energy efficiency in ways that create good jobs and lower bills, not just add new taxes and rules. I want my children to grow up with clean air and a stable climate, but I also need leaders to respect people’s livelihoods and privacy instead of forcing one-size-fits-all solutions.

I believe we need to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to be practical and protect people’s jobs and the basic cost of living. Climate policies should encourage responsible use of resources and support cleaner technologies, but not through heavy-handed regulations that cripple small businesses or drive up gas and electricity so families can’t make ends meet. We should focus on common-sense measures, like improving efficiency and promoting American energy independence, instead of drastic changes that hurt working people.

As someone who’s seen industries come and go in North Carolina, I don’t think we can treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposing sides anymore—they have to move in tandem. We should invest heavily in clean energy, efficiency, and conservation, not only because it’s our moral responsibility as stewards of God’s creation, but because it can create stable, good-paying jobs and new industries. Climate policy should put strict limits on pollution while supporting workers and communities in the transition, so we’re not leaving people behind as we do the right thing for future generations.
